tasks: Create a simple wireframe of a login flow using the 8-point grid system, focusing on typography and layout. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/8-point-grid-system) Score improvement: +2% for UX Fundamentals

Write down 5 common errors that occur during user research and validation, and brainstorm ways to mitigate them. (Reference: https://nngroup.com/articles/ten-usability-heuristics/) Score improvement: +1% for User Research & Validation

Design a basic prototype of a product feature using Figma or Sketch, focusing on usability and accessibility. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/aesthetic-usability-effect/) Score improvement: +1% for UI Craft & Visual Design

Conduct a self-assessment of your current design process, identifying 3 areas where you can improve collaboration with stakeholders. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/teslers-law/) Score improvement: +1% for Collaboration & Communication

Create a mind map of the 10 Usability Heuristics, highlighting key principles and best practices. (Reference: https://www.nngroup.com/articles/ten-usability-heuristics/) Score improvement: +2% for UX Fundamentals

Develop a simple usability test plan for a hypothetical product feature, including participant recruitment and data analysis. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/hicks-law/) Score improvement: +1% for User Research & Validation

Design a comprehensive product strategy document outlining your approach to user research, usability testing, and accessibility. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/laws-of-ux/) Score improvement: +5% for Product Thinking & Strategy
Create a final portfolio piece that showcases your design process, including wireframes, prototypes, and usability test results. (Score improvement: +10% across all categories)

resources.readup: As an Explorer UX designer, you have the unique opportunity to craft user experiences that ignite curiosity and spark meaningful connections. By leveraging your skills in user research, visual design, and collaboration, you can help shape products that are both functional and emotionally resonant.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Understanding Hick's Law and its Application in UX Design
topics.summary: Applying Hick's Law to optimize navigation and reduce cognitive load for users.
practice_points: Analyze 3 existing websites and identify areas where Hick's Law is applied (e.g., dropdown menus, navigation bars). Document findings and suggest improvements.
Design a simple navigation system with 5-7 options and test it using the Hick's Law formula to determine optimal number of options for users.

topics.name: Conducting User Research with the Jobs-to-be-Done Framework
topics.summary: Using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework to understand user motivations and behaviors.
practice_points: Conduct 2 interviews using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework with users from different demographics. Document findings and identify patterns.

topics.name: Applying Aesthetic-Usability Effect in UI Design
topics.summary: Using color, typography, and spacing to create an aesthetically pleasing and usable interface.
practice_points: Create 3 wireframes with different color schemes and ask users to rate their usability. Analyze results and suggest improvements.

insights.detailed: The score of 14 indicates that the designer has a basic understanding of fundamental principles such as user-centered design, wireframing, and usability testing. However, there is room for improvement in applying these principles to create a more intuitive and user-friendly experience.
actionable: Take online courses or attend workshops to refresh knowledge on UX fundamentals
Study successful designs and analyze what makes them effective
Conduct usability testing with real users to identify areas for improvement

insights.brief: Score meaning for UI Craft & Visual Design
insights.detailed: The score of 18 suggests that the designer has a solid foundation in visual design principles, color theory, and typography. However, there is still an opportunity to refine skills in creating visually appealing and consistent designs.
actionable: Join online communities or forums to stay updated on design trends and best practices
Participate in design challenges or hackathons to practice new skills
Study the work of renowned designers and analyze their visual design decisions

insights.brief: Score meaning for User Research & Validation
insights.detailed: The score of 18 indicates that the designer has a good understanding of research methods, user personas, and validation techniques. However, there is room for improvement in applying these skills to inform design decisions.
actionable: Conduct user interviews or surveys to gather insights on user needs and pain points
Analyze user feedback and data to identify trends and patterns
Collaborate with stakeholders to ensure research findings are actionable

insights.brief: Score meaning for Product Thinking & Strategy
insights.detailed: The score of 12 suggests that the designer has a basic understanding of product thinking and strategy, but may need to develop skills in areas such as market research, competitive analysis, and business goals alignment. This can impact the design's ability to meet user needs and achieve business objectives.
actionable: Take courses or attend workshops on product management and strategy
Study successful products and analyze their features, pricing, and marketing strategies
Collaborate with cross-functional teams to understand business goals and priorities

insights.detailed: The score of 16 indicates that the designer has a good understanding of collaboration principles, communication styles, and stakeholder management. However, there is still an opportunity to refine skills in facilitating effective team discussions and managing conflicting opinions.
actionable: Practice active listening and ask clarifying questions during meetings
Develop a clear and concise design language to ensure consistency across projects
Establish open communication channels with stakeholders to manage expectations
